title: 105_hr2673
content: The "Trigger Lock Act of 1997" may be cited as the short title. It includes provisions for child safety locks on firearms. The "Trigger Lock Act of 1997" mandates that firearms in the United States must have a locking device attached during transfer, with penalties for violations. The Secretary imposes fines and license suspensions or revocations on firearms dealers and manufacturers who violate the requirement to have a locking device attached to handguns during transfer. Effective 18 months after the enactment of this Act, it will be illegal to manufacture a handgun in the US without a locking device meeting minimum quality standards. Violators will face a $25,000 fine and potential license suspension or revocation. Additionally, 60 days after the effective date, transferring a firearm without notice and warning will be prohibited. Effective 60 days after the enactment of this Act, licensed importers, manufacturers, or dealers cannot transfer a handgun without a warning printed in ¾-inch type about responsible firearm storage and the risks of misuse. Failure to properly store a firearm may result in legal consequences. Federal law prohibits the possession of a handgun by a minor in most circumstances. Penalties for violations include a civil fine of $10,000 for licensed dealers or importers and a $5,000 fine for licensed manufacturers. Additionally, licenses may be suspended or revoked for those who violate the law. Federal law prohibits minors from possessing handguns, with penalties including fines for licensed dealers and manufacturers. Licenses may be suspended or revoked for violations. Government entities are exempt from these regulations. Individuals can seek judicial review within 60 days of receiving notice of a fine or license suspension from the Secretary. Federal law prohibits minors from possessing handguns, with penalties including fines for licensed dealers and manufacturers. Licenses may be suspended or revoked for violations. An adult leaving a loaded firearm or unloaded firearm with ammunition for a minor is unlawful unless supervised by an adult not prohibited from possessing a firearm. Violating section 922(y) can result in a fine of up to $10,000, imprisonment for up to 1 year, or both. The National Institute of Justice and the Consumer Product Safety Commission are conducting studies on developing quality standards for locking devices. The Director of the Centers for Disease Control will conduct a study on the results of the section regarding firearms storage. A report containing the findings of the study must be submitted to the Attorney General and the Secretary of the Treasury within 18 months. Additionally, up to $1,000,000 is authorized for educational programs on firearm storage. Within 6 months of enactment, the Secretary will issue regulations for locking devices on firearms. The term "locking device" refers to a device that, when activated, prevents the firearm from being discharged. The Secretary will issue regulations for locking devices on firearms within 6 months of enactment. A locking device prevents a firearm or handgun from being discharged when activated.
